name: Abram, William
comment: "Bill" is very studious and stands well in his classes; he is not too busy however to partake in the other college activities. Says that he is flunking Campus Lab, but his actions prove him false.

name: Adams, Neil
comment: A quiet, good-hearted, hard-working member of the '13 class. He is destined to make a good engineer. Sometimes has acrobatic "fits."

name: Aldrich, Sperry W.
comment: "Dutch" is one of the strong arms of our class. He is a friend to all who know him, probably because of his unlimited happiness.

name: Allender, Merwyn M.
comment: Found that eggs won't hatch at 115 degrees at I. S. C. One of the regular dodgers of Margaret Hall. A good all-round fellow.

name: Allstrand, Harry P.
comment: Has a high-rated "H. P." and is possessed of great ability to earn much in a short time. He spends his summer and winter vacations very profitably and returns to our midst to do more than his share in the various branches of college activity.

name: Arentson, James A.
clubs: Asst. Y. M. C. A. Secretary
comment: Good-hearted as you ever find and a man with a sturdy character. Another one of those chaps who "flopped" in his course to become an Ag. Engineer.

name: Armour, Harvey B.
comment: "And still the wonder grew, how one small head could carry all he knew." Always has plenty to do and always does it. Is slightly deficient in Campus Lab but intends to double on the last exam.

name: Arthur, Edna
comment: She is just the quiet kind whose virtues never vary. Reserved in her attitude toward the stronger sex. Makes brilliant recitations in Chem. 60.

name: Ashby, William W.
comment: William Wallace is one of the few Junior Ag. Engineers who started that course in their freshman year. He is a hard worker and gets results. His chief fault lies in the fact that he has not turned some of his surplus energy into other college activities.

name: Bacon, Frank R.
comment: A hard and sincere worker, not only for himself along agricultural lines, but for the '13's on the diamond and the gym floor. Incidentally, he is no relation to Hamm.

name: Bancroft, John S.
comment: "Pretty is as pretty does" and yet he is practical and knows a good "critter" when he sees it. He also believes in helping the laundry keep things clean.

name: Barker, Howard C.
comment: "There is nothing ill can dwell in such a temper." Howard is out after the best. He showed this when he came all the way from Indiana in order to attend a good school. By hard work and true loyalty, he has won an enviable place in the hearts of his classmates.

name: Barker, W. Earl
comment: Look who's here! He's just been out greasing the windmill. Barker is always inclined to study too hard, and yet he does his share toward other college activities, so let him study, it won't hurt him.

name: Barney, Fayette
comment: The notes just roll off the ends of "Fay's" fingers. In spite of the fact that he plays, and plays, and plays, he knows more than a few things about cheese, butter, and other pleasures of Prof. Mortenson's Department.

name: Batchelder, D. T.
comment: You can't say he is a roughhouser, but he believes in a good time. He can study, too, when occasion demands. Here is a man who is true to his name.

name: Baxter, L. J.
comment: Industrious and hardworking, but little given to self-assertion. Had literary ambitions once, but they drew too hard on his constitution, so he thought.

name: Bell, Lucile
comment: Lucile comes to us from the University of Nebraska, and we are glad to welcome her. Even though she is solemn as a "Monk" at times, she can be just as jolly as anyone when so inclined.

name: Bird, Catherine
comment: A regular little "Jenny Wren" with her soft voice and gentle ways. She is seldom seen about the campus because of the place she so beautifully fills in her home.

name: Bird, Paul
comment: "The world delights in a man who plays his own part." Quiet and unassuming. Does not push himself forward but goes his way like a man.

name: Bisbee, Earl
comment: Likes to go to Des Moines. Met his "fate" at the Drake-Ames game there this year. Is a good basketball player and an all-around good fellow with many friends.

name: Bliss, Callie May
comment: Can write as good poetry as Longfellow himself. Came to us from Drake. Wouldn't roll matches when a prep but has fully recovered from this stubbornness. Good-hearted and a good worker.

name: Bone, Joe
comment: Joe would make a good Squire, for he looks over those glasses just right. His laugh is characteristic, and his heart is as large as his store of knowledge.

name: Bonner, Gladys K.
comment: "I would the Gods had made thee poetical." Can grow as poetical over a soggy potato as over a fleecy cloud. Knows as much English and Lit. as the law allows. Has aspirations in the Public Speaking Department. Calm and peaceful as the dewy morn.

name: Bonsteel, Myron M.
comment: "Bon" is easygoing, quiet, and reserved. He will succeed by his very steadiness. Is a lover of the cinder path and gives his share of attention to the upkeep of its smoothness. He is good-natured and well-liked.

name: Bouton, E. M.
comment: A firm believer in St. Patrick's Day even though he can trace his ancestry back to Wilhelm Tell. "Bon Bon" is a staunch comrade, a man of action, and a good fellow.

name: Boyts, Harry J.
comment: Always ready and willing to push any good cause. If Dakota has more like him, they are welcome at Ames. Is some "fusser" but prejudiced to high school girls.

name: Bradford, Bernice
comment: "The sunshine is red when it shines on his head." —Dante. One of the "stars" in Professor Brindley's Economics class. He is fond of "pipe dreams."

name: Brasted, Orin R.
comment: One of the prime movers at Alumni Hall. Enjoys a good practical joke, is a thorough student, and a non-ladies' man.

name: Brown, David K.
comment: Dave is a happy-hearted lad and can crack a joke or tell a funny story with the best of them. Thinks he will be the editor of his home paper some day.

name: Brumhall, J. H.
comment: An unobtrusive lad and most reticent concerning his past. Is popular with his fellow classmates. Believes in doing his own work and is well up in his studies.

name: Burge, Charles A.
comment: The man whose wonderful toe sent Ames to the top of the "heap" in the State and Missouri Valley football struggle in 1911. Admired as a student and an athlete.

name: Burlingham, C. Lloyd
comment: "He's witty and he's wise, And he's got bright eyes." Girls seem to take a liking to "Doc," probably because he is a "live wire."

name: Burnett, Lloyd C.
comment: Noted for being unable to run a bluff in class, but he gets there just the same. To be admired because he saw a better school than the one in his own town.

name: Butler, Lyle A.
comment: He travels the cinder path frequently because it makes him dizzy to ride "fast" on the college car. Is often discovered bound for "home" to spend the evening.

name: Cairy, Forest W.
comment: A little man with lots of "Pep." Was a '12 but quit them as soon as he got acquainted with the '13's. "Pedie" is a good student and has lots of friends.

name: Campbell, Clyde B.
comment: Studious and conscientious but withal a cheerful sort of fellow. Here with the definite purpose of getting an education.

name: Chamberlain, Mark O.
comment: Inclined to create a sensation. Mark is forever boasting the wonderful "Union" in the Civil Structures class. By putting two and two together, we change his name to "Question Mark."

name: Chatburn, Guy
comment: "Chattie" is always friendly. He has a fine system in the "fussing game"—he dates "her" up the first week for every event in the term. He showed his dauntless courage by classifying in a five-year course of engineering.

name: Chatterjee, Brahma N.
comment: "Chat" is a good-natured man from India. Says he has picked up a lot of slang in America if he never learns anything else. Can appreciate a joke better than most of us.

name: Clapp, Paul
comment: "None but himself can be his parallel." Notwithstanding his varied activities, Paul is leading the race for first honors. As thoughtful of others as he is of himself. A true and sincere friend.

name: Clark, Clifford K.
comment: This man is not Greek although one might think so after reading above. A regular stone wall on the class football team and a good big fellow off of it. You can bank on Clark making good for that is his way.

name: Clutter, J. A.
comment: Likes "Noble" deeds. Makes a "dashing" appearance in the spring, always bringing honor to his school and class. He is little, but Oh My!

name: Cochran, Clyde F.
comment: "Banty" can always be counted on when there is anything doing in any line. Has a keen sense of humor and remarkable ingenuity. Travels at the railroad's expense.

name: Cochran, Morris C.
comment: The kind of man you like. Cheerful and friendly with an utter lack of conceit. Never interferes with other people. Came past a good school to get to a better one.

name: Cochrane, William F.
clubs: Business Manager-elect I. S. C. Student
comment: "A heart as true as steel." Sincerity and heroism have brought Bill the high esteem and regard of every member of the class. He is noted as King of the Sophomores and a prominent figure in St. Patrick's Day parade.

name: Coe, Howard S.
comment: Not so sober-minded as his hair might indicate. A jolly good fellow and a broad-minded one.

name: Conlee, Glenn L.
comment: Glenn is one of those quiet workers who never interferes with other people's business. He was one of the first to wear his 1913 sweater. P. S. And he is wearing it yet.

name: Conlee, Harold E.
comment: Harold is one of those fellows who makes friends with everybody. He is particularly fond of mechanics, but only wishes that the Phys. Dept. would handle it.

name: Costigan, George L.
comment: Costigan is one of the chronic cinder-path walkers. He is a lad who is well liked by his bunch although he is a great "kidder." It is said that he plays with the Ames Tigers during vacation.

name: Coverdale, Roy E.
comment: Good-looking and as good-natured. His speed varies inversely as his size. He will make a stock judge yet if he keeps at it. Much opposed to girls getting their dates mixed, especially when he is concerned.

name: Crawford, A. Jesse
comment: Did you say that he liked "Hazel" eyes? Spike can sing like a nightingale and can clear a bar easily.

name: Crawford, Arch R.
comment: Wields his pen fluently (look for his signature.) The best cartoonist I. S. C. ever had. Always good-natured, has a fondness for "Eve"-ning dates with little "Persons." He is also musically inclined.

name: Crocker, Thomas F.
comment: A man who is very confident of himself. Favorite expression, "Why, I could do anything if I but had the power." Tom is a fine lad and well liked by all the class.

name: Crowley, Orville W.
comment: Here's a jovial Irishman who spends all of his odd moments watching the post office to see if a letter arrives from the "loved one" at home. Cheer up Crowley, this is no school for "love making."

name: Daly, Claude C.
comment: Daly had the misfortune to break his arm last winter, but it takes more than that to put him out of the race. He is Gen. Lincoln's right-hand man and an officer in the I. N. G. "Cap" can be depended upon to do the right thing.

name: D'Antremont, Frank J.
comment: "Dant" is a large, undecided blonde who thinks "Chi" town is too smoky. He would rather be late than hurry a thousand times over. Often evades the railroad conductors.

name: Darbyshire, Glen
comment: Can't decide whether to be an Ag. or a Vet. Had ambitions to be a professor in botany and begin by tutoring but was not appreciated. "Darby" can apply himself and will no doubt make a success when he has finished both Ag. and Vet.

name: Dickinson, Sherman
comment: A good business manager. "Storms" around when angry but he soon subsides. "Dickie" was one of the unlucky four in the Junior-Freshman football game. Makes a charming Cleopatra.

name: Dibine, E. R.
comment: A gentleman who showed his good judgment when he left his own state and came to I. S. C. to pursue his chosen line of work. A man of double thought, who never leaps until he looks. "Divy" has a fondness for pretty girls. Delights in going to the Princess.

name: Dolcini, Valente
comment: "Dolly" is a stockman from start to finish. He came a long way to find a school where he could put in his time to the best advantage. Sheep and horses aren't the only subjects with which he is familiar either—comedy is as easy for "Dolly" as placing them 3-1-4-2.

name: Dorchester, Charles S.
comment: Thoroughly enjoys starting something and usually is there to finish it. Gets a "daily" from home but is also making good grades in "Campus Lab." Popular, a good fellow and a good student.

name: Doty, Lewis J.
comment: Lew is a rather timid fellow who joined the Vets after taking a trial at Ag. Went to Minneapolis one time just to see if he could—and he did. Almost a Sophomore but his ability to carry more extra work has made him a No. 1 Junior.

name: Doyle, Bernard L.
comment: Likes I.S.C. all right but believes Nevada has "the prettier girls." Thinks Vet. studies are hard to remember but there is one "Page" he never will forget. Doyle is a hard worker and a good student.

name: Egert, Benjamin J.
comment: "Ben" is one of those quiet, unassuming chaps who wins friends without trying. Has shown his ability as an M.E. by the manufacture of a gasoline engine. His chapel ticket for the first semester cost him a quarter.

name: Ellis, Percy L.
comment: No relation to the "mechanism man" for "brains he has." Never busy at studies but always prompt with a good answer. Has an intelligent countenance that is not deceiving.

name: Evans, R. M.
comment: One of the wonderful "Civils" who believes in a closed shop. A good student when he is studiously inclined and studies late several nights in each term in order to catch up with the work he missed while oversleeping. Good-hearted and a good mixer.

name: Fensler, H. M.
comment: "Squeak" is a "was-er" of the '12's but flagged school in '11. After deciding that he couldn't stay away from good old I. S. C., came back and requested admittance into the class of '13. Popular and a good student.

name: Fenton, Faith
comment: Has a nickname that suits. Gets high grades but "modesty hides her light under a bushel." Was never shocked in her life. Not given to wild enthusiasms. A quiet, unassuming Quaker maiden.

name: Ferguson, Howard C.
comment: "The rattle of a typewriter is music to my ears." "Fergy" is a steady old war horse who does lots of outside work while most of us are enjoying ourselves. He doesn't have to waste much time combing his hair, but is always ready to help his friends or listen to a good story.

name: Fick, Adolph
comment: Energetic and always seems to be going to do something. Adolph has given four speeches in P. S. 14 on "The Troubles of a Concrete Inspector on the Chicago and Northwestern Railway." We are led to believe that he has worked for the Northwestern.

name: Finley, Edson L.
comment: Likes to work, but is fully as enthusiastic over a good time. Is said to have just missed getting a scholarship once. A shark in Chem., but said it was due to his knowing just when to laugh (?)

name: Fisher, Charles M.
comment: "Monty" can take better astronomical readings than anyone else in the class. He is never so downhearted that he hasn't a grin and cheerful "hello" for everyone.

name: Frazier, Everett H.
comment: "Chick" is not to be mistaken for the taller one in Fisher's famous cartoons. He is one of the best-hearted, jolliest members we have.

name: Gage, Helen
comment: Helen seems to be quite partial to textiles. Perhaps it is because they are studying the "History of Cotton." Helen is an attractive girl, and the '13 class is proud to own her.

name: Gates, Levi S.
comment: A big man with a big heart. Next to Connie Mack, Levi's hero is Sir Walter Raleigh, who realized the pleasure of a good smoke. A steady fellow and always ready for work.

name: Gatewood, Ray
comment: "Ye Gods, how he can shake his feet." Never known to hold still. He made the fellows work for their places on the Stock Judging Team in 1911. Everybody likes him, even the girls.

name: Gilchrist, Clifford M.
comment: Besides being a good student, "Gilly" has time to act as "Orchard Guide" during apple season and deliver eggs to the Zoo Dept. in the winter. Says he never fusses, but always blushes when the name "Gladys" is mentioned.

name: Gillette, Chester S.
comment: "Gillie" and "Dean Roe" can be depended upon to raise prize-winning porkers for I. S. C. He is not satisfied with much less than a perfect grade, either.

name: Girton, Earl S.
comment: Big and boyish. Flirts on the trains. Likes Percherons and Durocs. A very capable fellow and a good friend wherever you find him.

name: Glaze, Clifford H.
comment: "Blessings on him who first cultivated the weed." This big-hearted man has made good from the start. He first showed that he was equal to all occasions by the way he fooled the "hazers" in those good old days. We only wish that all Ames men were as practical as "Cliff."

name: Graham, D. W.
comment: Yes, here's the big fellow with the pompadour who takes tickets at the Princess. "Tubby" would rather do this and read a paper than study, but somehow he is strong on the finish and is still in the class of '13.

name: Gratiot, Joseph B.
comment: "Joe" never gets in a hurry; in fact, he has all the time in the world. He makes his head work, though, and is keeping pace with the rest of us.

name: Hackett, Shirley M.
comment: A man with the right idea. He is here to get the most possible good out of his course. Never too busy to help a classmate when called upon.

name: Hamm, J. R.
comment: "Dick" doesn't believe in overworking but has no trouble keeping up with his class. A quiet, well-liked "thirteen-er." Chose to take Civil because he liked railroad work—in the "Parlor Car."

name: Hall, Harry W.
comment: Not W. W. but H. W. Hall from West Liberty; the only real authority on "Fleabitis" (Phlebitis). Started with the class of '12 but was afraid he'd overstudy so stayed out a year. "Gusty's" all right.

name: Hall, Oro W.
comment: "Fat" doesn't believe in wasting an overly amount of time in worrying. Plods along slowly but surely, and always gets there when the final chimes ring out. Perfectly innocent, for he frequents only Nevada.

name: Hanson, Marie
comment: Her calm wasn't even ruffled when her hair caught fire in the Chem. Lab. Moves slowly and with precision. Has a great deal of stick-to-it-iveness.

name: Harmon, Guy C.
comment: Here is a man that you can't fool on a dairy cow. Never known to "fuss," unless it was over the placing of a dairy class.

name: Hassell, Willard C.
comment: Noted for his long-distance sleep records. Not given to talking much but a keen observer. Full of dry wit and perfectly able to apply it.

name: Harpel, Gates
comment: Gates was one of the heroes of the Pi Phi fire. He aided "Red" Allstrand and Truman Manning in escaping unnoticed out of the back door after they had put out the fire. A good worker for his class.

name: Harte, Edwin C.
comment: "Busty's" true worth lies beneath the surface. He is never so happy as when tearing up an opposing line. One of those unassuming fellows whom we all like to know.

name: Hartung, Arthur C.
comment: Decided he would graduate with the good people, so stayed at home last year. A good Ames booster.

name: Hartung, Mary E.
comment: Mary is a good student. Her favorite expression, "That makes me so mad." She is a girl whom anyone might be glad to own as a friend.

name: Hawks, Georgena
comment: "Let's talk, my friends, let's talk." Never caught napping when fun is at hand. Always ready to smile out loud. Will have two degrees when she finishes. A shark but doesn't know it.

name: Helm, Ralph L.
comment: "Shorty" hasn't missed a Friday night Assembly this year. Dancing is his hobby, but it doesn't interfere with his college work the rest of the week.

name: Helsel, Frank V.
comment: Here we have "Dad," a firm believer in two old adages, "Never too old to learn," and "Save the pennies and the dollars will take care of themselves." A little small in stature but makes up for it in gray matter.

name: Hensel, R. H.
comment: "Don't do that, boy, will you?" "Texas nor Colorado neither one come up to Ames as a school." "Tex" can handle music as well as forestry problems. "The conservation of our forests is one of the greatest problems confronting the U.S."

name: Hess, Arthur W.
comment: Hess is one of the members of the '13 class who is making a study of the scientific management of the pick and shovel. A loyal worker for the Engineering magazine. Spares no pains in striving to understand the theory and practice of that which he undertakes.

name: Hicken, R. H.
comment: A quiet fellow who takes a great interest in his work. Classifies heavy and makes high grades. A poultry judge and knows a good dairy cow when he sees her.

name: Hill, Carlos V.
comment: "C. V." is one of the fellows who thinks that man was made to work. That's what he came here for and that's what he does—all the time. Strongly in favor of "Prep" Rules. A poet and storyteller of no mean ability.

name: Hoff, Carl R.
comment: It is a "toss up" with Carl which is the best to play—baseball or work with machinery. He would rather do either than eat.

name: Hoot, Denver W.
comment: "Good things are put up in small parcels." This little man has a habit of getting everything as he goes. He is as wise as an owl but does not "Hoot" like one; far from it. When he has something to say, it is worth hearing. A good student and a loyal Engineer.

name: Hopkins, A. L.
comment: With his quiet and gentlemanly manner, he has won many friends among his classmates and associates. "Hop" doesn't believe in ruining health by excessive study but encounters little trouble in keeping up with his class.

name: Hopkins, Blanche
comment: "It's not so much the words you say, as the way in which you say them." Kind words are always spoken by her, for she knows no other. She is conscientious and reserved. Her voice is ever soft, gentle, and low—an excellent thing in woman.

name: Hopkins, Ruby
comment: "A better, jollier I never knew."—Ade. "Cupid" loves picnics. She is noted for always being in a rush. Always has a pleasant smile and an "Oh, you get out"—for her friends. She has taken all the Lit. that is offered and now she is taking economics. Declares that she likes John Brindley's classes.

name: Horton, Floyd V.
comment: Used to go to dairy judging and prep drill in an auto. Nothing slow about "Hort." Likes his subject and is going to follow it up.

name: Horton, Guy
comment: "Hort" entered with the '12s but went out west and worked long enough to finish with the '13s. He divides his time about equally between the south and west sides. His chief delight is hopping over the "sticks" or working Phys.

name: House, Harry M.
comment: Perhaps "Happy House" would have been a more appropriate name for this young hustler, but be that as it may, we have here one of the "live" workers of the Junior class. Always boosting for I.S.C. is this small man with a big heart. He also goes by the name of the "Gold Dust Twin."

name: House, Wilbur M.
comment: This is to be one of the "House Bro's Engineering Contractors" corporation of the future. An energetic electrical engineer is this member of the Junior class, and one who is always on deck when there is work at hand. He passes up "shops" as fast as the college can furnish the material. Has been known to drink—black coffee.

name: Howland, Paul R.
comment: This is a steady "old war horse" who can be depended upon when there is work to be done. Nobody appreciates an Ames victory more than "Doc" and none are more ready to celebrate it. In spite of this, however, he gets all there is to be had and is bound to make good.

name: Hudson, William J.
comment: "A wise son maketh a glad father." "Hud" is so busy pulling high grades that he seldom has time for anything else. He has passed up everything except Campus Lab and says that unless given credit for summer work he will flunk that.

name: Huebsch, Leila H.
comment: "What she wills to do or say is wise, virtuous and best." Hails from Cornell and we were mighty glad to get her. Has lots of energy and "pep" and will see a thing through to a finish.

name: Hunt, Donald A.
comment: The old reliable, good-hearted, curly-headed football man. A mighty hard worker and a true man in every sense.

name: Hunter, Clyde H.
comment: This "killer" made his first hit at Ames in 1909. Since then he has spent his time wherever there are ladies. Studies frequently and is a devoted follower of the big bass drum.

name: Illeman, John A.
comment: A tall, blonde-thatched youth, who has won the respect of his friends by his quiet, earnest ways. One of his qualities is truly worth knowing.

name: Johnson, Earl H.
comment: "Johnse" can't understand why the other fellows go to his home town oftener than he does. Has never been arrested for disturbing the peace of his neighbors. An earnest worker with a bright future.

name: Johnson, Howard C.
comment: A practical man who never worries. Has kept up his finances by barbering during his spare time. Seemed to have a failing for Murphy's Phys. but deserves a great deal of credit for his persistent efforts.

name: Johnson, J. B.
comment: "I. B." has legs long enough to reach to the ground and a head to correspond. He was high man among the Missouri Valley apple judges in 1911. A good man wherever he goes.

name: Johnson, Paul
comment: He is very quiet and reserved, but that is because he is thinking. The Prof. never catches him, for lessons are a joy and what he came here to get.

name: Johnston, Harold E.
comment: This fellow was not quite adapted to college life at first but is being rapidly changed by his environment into quite a sociable student. Gets good grades and works hard during his spare time as attendant and handy man at the Vet hospital.

name: Johnston, J. R.
comment: You never see this man on the campus when he's not following a block of meerschaum around. "Johnse" is full of enthusiasm that comes out in appropriate remarks.

name: Jonker, Herman H.
comment: "He was just a rare good fellow." Too lively and good-looking to ever study much but keeps up with the average anyway. Lost his shoes in the high water at Des Moines one time but no further losses were reported.

name: Jordan, Hugo G.
comment: One of our foreign students who has "made good" at I. S. C. A charter member of the "Fussing Club." Brilliant in his studies and an interesting talker when you once know him.

name: Joy, O. H.
comment: He likes to fuss but hasn't a chronic case. A mighty good friend and well-liked by all. A strong booster for Logan.

name: Juhl, Chris
comment: A big open-hearted fellow who is liked by all who know him. Some football man too. Came to Ames from Drake and has always been glad he made the change.

name: Kerr, Harry A.
comment: Here is one who could see the greatness of Ames even from an adjoining state. He also decided to leave the 12's and graduate with a good class.

name: Kilby, Don H.
comment: A busy body from the word go. Don spends lots of time working for others while they are working for themselves. He has no objection to 'fussing' as a pastime. Nevertheless he is an all-around fine fellow and a loyal '13.

name: Kriethe, Paul F.
comment: "I inherited the German language." In his quiet, good-natured way, "Pete" is the kind of a fellow that will make Ames proud of her sons and daughters.

name: Laird, Ralph J.
comment: "Skin" hails from Algona and is the only real ladies' man we have among the Vets. Has a commission in the I.N.G. from which he gets his ideas on "How to Soldier." Quite a popular fellow and a great "Speeler."

name: Lawton, J. A.
comment: Direct from the farm, "Ick" came to us to gambol in the realm of science and enjoy the routine of a college life. His regularity and willingness to help have made him one of the standpatters of the '13 class.

name: Leedham, Tom W.
comment: Tom is determined to pass up his "calc" and get started on a clean slate if the "Profs" will give him half a chance. He's a hard worker and a good loser when luck turns against him.

name: Lebsen, Paul C.
comment: Levi's curves keep them all guessing. Makes a good appearance in the pitcher's box. His fiddlin' makes you dance clear up to heaven—with never a reverse.

name: List, Theodore S.
comment: "Teddy" is easily distinguished from the rest of us by his jewelry. Say, did you ever notice those diamonds? Some class, hey? Too quiet most of the time, but awfully noisy if once roused up.

name: Lissenden, Clyde H.
comment: With troubles crowded upon him, unknown to the average student, he has faithfully plodded on toward the goal of the "sheepskin." A hard worker in and out of school. Experienced at the sale of groceries and through his numerous agencies he has obtained a business training along with his "scientific" education.

name: Lynch, Ruby
comment: Plays "All That I Ask Is Love" for Miss Tilden's gym classes. Willing; helps to rescue the Freshmen from the mathematical whirlpool.

name: McBride, F. W.
comment: "Hop to it," Mac, get all out of Ames you can for those folks back home are depending on your bringing a lot back. "Mac" likes to work in the library (if the right librarian is there).

name: McChord, Robert C.
comment: "Bob" is one of the most popular men in school. He comes from the Sunny South but he does like to coast. He is quiet but has a strong personality. Things looked bright to him until lately when they have been looking a little "Gray."

name: McClintock, Ruth
comment: Perhaps one reason she never has a care is because she forgets all but the passing moment. Heartily enjoys wild adventures, such as a breakfast in the North Woods in a snowstorm. Makes a splendid coon and can sing "The Barber Shop Chord" with the best of expression. Ruth is a jolly good girl and gets good grades.

name: McDonald, John R.
comment: "Destined to laugh and make money." "Mack" makes his regular trips to Boone, but it is not for the "Handle With Care" goods or the shoebox variety. Hello "John."

name: McDonald, Myrtle
comment: A girl who comes and goes as she pleases. Always attending to her own duties in a quiet way which is characteristic of her. Has a "stand in" in French.

name: McDonald, Roy
comment: "Mac" has a faculty for laughing off trouble and making friends. His smiling, pleasing ways have won for him a home in many hearts. He is always on the job and especially would he forfeit luxury for an opportunity to put in time on the football field.

name: McKim, Elizabeth
comment: Although she works when she works, she is never too busy to enjoy life. Dependable and capable. We are glad to have her among us.

name: McKitterick, Robert N.
comment: We have before us the expert eraser thrower of the Junior Mechanical class. He has been known to give orations in Prof. Major's descriptive engineering class, and to carry heavy parts in the entertainment furnished in the Junior designing "lab." "Mac" was never known to be offensive.

name: McMicheal, Harry A.
comment: "Mike" ought to have specialized in oratory rather than stock raising. At least it is by public speaking (not in class or on the stage) that we know him.

name: McMillan, Ralph O.
comment: "Mac" has the sunniest of temperaments. He manages to dip into everything from welcoming freshmen to managing athletic affairs. Through his zeal in the former activity we were almost afraid we had lost him at one time, but he "came back" and his smile is still with us.

name: Macklin, William E.
comment: Born in China but came to America as soon as he found it out. Bill is the distinguished author of "Diseases of the Calf" and Macklin's "Joke Book." A great enthusiast of athletics.

name: Martin, Edgar E.
comment: With the aid of a powerful microscope it was discovered Sept. 4, 1909 that "Cutie" was among the '13's. In spite of his size however, he has made lots of friends. In fact he became so popular the first week, that he proposed to a girl in the presence of upper classmen. "And her name was Rachael."

name: Melberg, Amos
comment: There is something decidedly agreeable about this importation. Possessed with a pleasing, quiet disposition, he is welcomed wherever he appears. We have heard that the girls line up on the depot platform when his train pulls into Norway.

name: Meltzer, William
comment: "Bill" says college life is just one continuous "gip." If it isn't quantitative chem., it's something worse. In spite of this, he gets there just the same.

name: Miller, George J.
comment: No matter what happens, George is there with the smile, whether the joke is on him or not. Has been known to come out to the college fussing.

name: Miller, Herbert
comment: "Herbie" has easily proved that he is endowed with his share of native wisdom. Never get in an argument with him, for he'll show you up every time. Also has a faculty for pulling high grades.

name: Miller, Virgil C.
comment: Came to Ames from the State Normal because he realized our better opportunities. He is always jovial and ready to visit. Great admirer of jolly girls.

name: Milligan, Harry W.
comment: "Mull" comes from Sioux City and carries out the true Irish type in his name and characteristics. Capable in his studies when so inclined, but shies at work. Got several encores in Phys.

name: Mitchell, Jennie
comment: An artist in gymnastics. Won second place in the Bomb Popularity Contest. Everyone knows and likes her. Has a winsome smile and is not a bit stingy with it.

name: Moore, Robert G.
comment: "Little Bobby" is of the same quality of goods as the larger brands. Upper Iowa's representative to I. S. C. and not such a bad one either. Says there is nothing he likes better than fussing, unless it's more (Moore).

name: Mosher, Frank A.
comment: "How can you do it 'Mose'?" Not exactly physically strong but upon his shoulders rest the responsibilities of a forest of undertakings. Always helping, never loafing. Frank is upholding more than his share of the dignity of the class of '13.

name: Mott, Claude H.
comment: Mott is one of those quiet, hard-working fellows. You cannot afford to let him get through college without cultivating his acquaintance. It has been rumored that he "fussed" once, but we have not been able to confirm the statement.

name: Myers, Bernard F.
comment: "Myers" is a man with one of those "still water" dispositions. His "runs deep" into everything pertaining to college work, especially along Animal Husbandry lines.

name: Nagle, Clarence F.
comment: "Spike" showed that he knew a good thing when he saw it by coming to Ames after spending two years at the Minnesota U. He is a loyal engineer and a true friend. Thanks, Minnesota! We shall take all you wish to give us like him.

name: Neis, Carl F.
comment: His name, rightly pronounced, is "Neese" but prefers being called "Nice." Carl is young and is sure to amount to something if he keeps on growing. Was never known to flunk and will be hard to beat for class honors.

name: Nelson, S. O.
comment: Quiet and reserved, but full of fun. Good-natured and a good worker. Although a trifle bashful, he uses it to good advantage and will come out ahead in the end.

name: Newburger, Lessing B.
comment: Closely resembles the illustrious "Spike." Noted for his public speeches. Quiet and "plows his own row."

name: Nordstrom, Royal F.
comment: "Jack" has that dignified yet pleasing way which makes a good "mixer." Will no doubt locate as near as possible to Cedar Rapids when he has finished his course.

name: Nordstrom, Harry M.
comment: Of a roaming nature and a high stepper. A bright student; quiet and possessed with good judgment. Well-liked by all who know him. A steady, loyal member of the class of 1913.

name: Nutty, Nathaniel S.
comment: Not exactly a star (shooting star), but generally stays by a thing until he gets it. Has them all beaten when it comes to making up work. "Nat" works for Judisch and runs the Vet. pharmacy during spare time.

name: Odendahl, Irve E.
comment: "Odey" is a past master of the mandolin. Except when raising the deuce on this instrument, he is quiet and well behaved. He is one of the few who don't worry about examinations.

name: Olsen, James C.
comment: "Jim" is a "getter" of grades, and always knows more than the "exam" questions call for. Of a quiet nature and well thought of by all with whom he comes in touch. Before this man lies the future of a wizard.

name: Olsen, Edward S.
comment: Has such a "stand in" with the faculty he is credited with work he never took. Ames is proud of him for he helped us tackle Iowa again, at wrestling.

name: Paine, Harry C.
comment: One of those "slow and steady by jerks" kind. "Lippy" has quit us once or twice but is now determined to stick it out. Not a few are the I.S.C. Co-eds who have had Paine in their hearts.

name: Patterson, Nellie R.
comment: A thorough student whose aim is to do her best. Prefers "Chem" Lab to "Campistry" Lab. Though small, she swings her tennis racket like an expert.

name: Perry, Thomas R.
comment: A real storybook detective. Always quick and accurate in answering the question, "Who done dot?" "Tommy" has taken just enough athletics to be able to give the college yell. Put a '13 banner on the post office and was the first man "stretched" by the '12s.

name: Peshak, Leona
comment: "A friend in need is a friend indeed." An indispensable worker and booster in all organizations. Her motto is, "A thing worth doing at all is worth doing well."

name: Peters, Mabel
comment: "Thank fortune I've passed up my Math at last." In a perpetual stew, she often sits up until two or three o'clock cramming for exams. During her "prep" days, climbed a transom. Laughs at her own eccentricities. "She talks but little (?)".

name: Pfeffer, C. J.
comment: "Peff", though a trifle modest, is always able to take care of himself. Even in Mechanics class, he had little trouble in running his bluff with the rest of them. He's not just full of pep, but would make an athlete if he were sufficiently urged. We hope he will return to finish his course.

name: Pfund, Hans C.
comment: This big, good-natured Dutchman is a typical college man. He is a good student, a star athlete, and has a host of friends. "Hans" doesn't let popularity affect his head but can always appreciate a joke even on himself.

name: Pickus, Joseph
comment: There is one thing "Joe" always insisted (?) upon—to be classified in mechanics under Prof. Porter. He is inclined to think that the work is crowded onto the engineers too extensively but is determined to be a "Civil" if it takes a lifetime.

name: Pitts, Ilma
comment: "To know her is to love her." Everything she undertakes is well done. Admired by her classmates.

name: Preston, Perry J.
comment: With a good "understanding," Perry wanders about from class to class, determined to get at least as much out of his course as can be gained by attending recitations. He has been known to talk very fluently without even being asked. Noted for his genial nature and large heart.

name: Prine, Edna
comment: Edna is a "good Indian," for she comes from Tama. She is kind and considerate and is always popular among her associates and friends.

name: Quint, Bryce A.
comment: "Bick" left for the East in '11, but I. S. C. rang in his head until he hurried back to pursue his original course of study. A bright student and a good mixer. Is especially interested in "Poultry Husbandry."

name: Reese, Joseph M.
comment: Seldom seen with a girl. His chief haunt is the Princess. One of the dandiest, orneriest, nicest, horridest boys in the Junior Class. Has a "Sunny Jim" smile which does one good to see. Always forgets to work until it is too late.

name: Reis, Raymond B.
comment: Has good characteristics too numerous to mention. One of the few students who can take part in the strenuous sidelines of college activity and yet keep his work above par in a stiff course.

name: Rice, Charles D.
comment: "Wise as an owl." A "thoroughbred" from Kentucky but has the "show me" characteristics of Missouri. "Seedy's" greatest delight is to corner the Profs. Liked chemistry so well he took a review (?) An instructor in poisonous plants lab.

name: Richardson, Willa
comment: She certainly is not so slow in skidding across the gym floor after a basketball. Is going to get honors in Public Speaking.

name: Ringheim, Horace J.
comment: One of the stand-bys in football and baseball. Can take the hard bumps as long as any.

name: Roberson, Frank
comment: "Robie" is the stoker and boiler tender of the E. E. class. He furnishes the power for lively times and has even made Prof. Major laugh. Good-hearted and true to his cause, is this member of the 13's.

name: Rogers, Raymond R.
comment: "Rog" is one of the happy mechanicals who is able to pass up his work without worrying. Easy-going, good-natured, and possesses a multitude of friends.

name: Ross, Roy G.
comment: "Keeping Busy" is just a habit with "Skeets," yet this no doubt accounts for his good record. He has been trying to make up his Campus Lab by correspondence and reports excellent progress. Receives a great many apologies for looking like Ellis.

name: Rush, Fern
comment: "She sleeps, my lady sleeps,"—at roll call. She's a puzzle. Calm, docile, and easygoing.

name: Sar, Martin E.
comment: Serious by nature with the courage of his convictions. A man who will make good in his line because of his perseverance.

name: Sarvis, Fred
comment: "Fritz" is the '13 man of mystery. If he wants to borrow a knife, he will call you over to the corner, see that no one is looking, and ask you for it. Can give all the good points of a "tampin' bar."

name: Sauerberg, Julia
comment: Julia always has someone to carry her books for her. She is noted for her blushes and is particularly interested in Ceramics. Since her assistant in Chem. has left, she has been compelled to rely upon Prof. Fowler for her information.

name: Schmidt, Ferdinand C.
comment: Let this be "Fen's" epitaph: "That there never was a harder worker, a better friend, a truer 'pal' or a jollier, bigger-hearted, all-around Dutchman than he."

name: Schreck, Robert G.
comment: Doesn't take a very active part in college doings but is well liked by those who come in contact with him. He takes the world as it comes and makes the best of it.

name: Schwab, John W.
comment: Lots of ability as an arguer and lots more in the line of the Ag. Experiment Station. He's the right-hand man at the Station. Also an exponent of the theory that one can do better work when surrounded by his own family than when living in the midst of a bunch of boys.

name: Schwertley, John H.
comment: An advocate of free transportation and a deriver of formulae for the bewilderment of railway conductors. The "shining light" of the Junior Mechanics class. Optimism personified.

name: Floyd, Scott A.
comment: Floyd changed from Agronomy to Ag. Education this year. He is a mighty fine fellow, a good worker, and a faithful football player.

name: Seba, J. Henry
comment: Quiet and thoughtful is this analyzer of milk. Claims that the reason for his staying at I.S.C. so long is because he's in love with his course of study. "Hank" declares he has passed up drill.

name: Secor, Manly
comment: Likes his work and is always in good humor. Is there with a cheerful "hello" whenever you see him. Grooms the banana tree at the greenhouse.

name: Shaffer, Lloyd P.
comment: A jolly good fellow from the Nebraska University. Some judge of dairy cattle.

name: Shallenberger, James K.
comment: After spending the summer among the cowboys of the West, "Troggie" returned to take up his old stand in the Junior Mechanical class. He has been known to be quiet for five to ten minutes at a time. Sometimes he studies for exams, and sometimes he studies the dictionary for big words.

name: Shaw, George C.
comment: "Gee whiz! No! He isn't going to ask us to derive that darn thing." George never could see why anyone could flunk a Physics exam. He is a good judge of stories but has no time for Campus Lab.

name: Shearer, Arthur B.
comment: A jolly good fellow who has been three years trying to decide whether to be a vet or a traveling man. Though never handed a bouquet, he has succeeded in getting a "Flower." "Brace" has the ability and will make good in his new work.

name: Shoemaker, Joseph J.
comment: "We could write volumes about Joe, But don't dare to tell all we know." Joe is a big man with a big heart. Whether in the classroom, leading a St. Patrick's parade, or acting the part of Rastus at a Margaret Hall Colonial party, he is a master hand.

name: Simpson, Arthur R.
comment: "Art" is a true friend and a good worker when he doesn't have that faraway look in his eyes which shows that he is thinking of the girl at Illinois. Smooth as they make 'em.

name: Smith, Milton O.
comment: "Monk" has moody spells but they don't last long. He is quite fond of "Bells." We will have to confess that Milton has a keen sense of humor and he always used to be fond of a little "Moore" than he had, but his tactics have changed now. Does his work well and possesses a multitude of friends.

name: Snyder, L. D.
comment: This man claims to be the cube root of a Scottish lord. Is well known on account of his good grades, but perhaps better known as the other one of the "Gold Dust Twins."

name: Steffen, Edwin H.
comment: He is trim and neat and carries a tidy smile. Don't tell anyone, but he is working for honors in Forestry.

name: Sterrett, J. C.
comment: No one was more surprised than "Mike" when he won the Freshman Stock Judging Contest. He likes Phys fine and appreciates his other work too.

name: Stookey, Carl W.
comment: "Fie! What a spendthrift she is of her tongue." His highest ambition is to become an M. E. We don't know whether this is Mechanical Engineering or Matrimonial Educator.

name: Stork, V. H.
comment: Much averse to the oleomargarine manufacture. "Vernie" is not going to let College life interfere with his studies, for he thinks it pays to be prepared when the classroom is approached.

name: Strickler, Omar M.
comment: "Strick" has the advantage over the other Dairys in the fact that he comes from a good town. Is an expert in testing cream. He is a hard worker; well liked by his friends, of whom he has many.

name: Sullivan, J. Butler
comment: "Sully" is composed of just as much grit as his namesake "John L." ever had. He is a straightforward, good-hearted, hardworking student. At track he has at least passed up drill, and we hope he will soon be able to do even greater things in the future.

name: Summers, Walter G.
comment: Would rather "rough house" than pay attention in class, but is perfectly innocent if closely watched. With a reach that exceeds the width of any regulation court, he is a shark at the game of tennis and has won many honors in this sport.

name: Swanson, Arthur C.
comment: "He bane a poor unlucky Swede feller." Nevertheless, he always gets there just the same, except for Monday morning classes. If you want to know a fellow of the good quiet kind, get acquainted with "Swede."

name: Taff, Paul C.
comment: Paul's ability to do work varies directly as the square of the time. He is the Extension Department's right-hand man. In fact, he divides his time about equally between college and outside work but always succeeds in doing as much in each as the ordinary man does in one.

name: Terrall, A. Jay
comment: This youth is as full of "pep" as a pepper box. He believes that a rough house is proper if carried on in a scientific manner. Nevertheless, "Levi" is practical and will make good. His highest ambition is to own a 320-acre Iowa farm.

name: Thompson, Lena
comment: "Tommy" is a mischievous, sarcastic little girl. We are not certain whether she expects to practice H. Ec. when she finishes school or run a dray line and burden "Trux" with her trunks.

name: Tong, Boyd H.
comment: "Tong" is a busy man and a hard worker. He has been known to do some government work. Quiet, thoughtful, ambitious, and well-liked by his classmates.

name: Torres, Ambrosio O.
comment: Torres is one of the members of our class from far away. A harder worker has never been enrolled at I. S. C. He takes a very deep interest in his work and is striving toward a goal worth reaching. Self-confidence is the characteristic possessed by this youth that will make him successful wherever he goes.

name: Triggs, Fred E.
comment: This is the man whom you have seen leading the '13 yells. He is a good mixer and a debater of "some class." Fred does not stop at college activities alone, as he spends his spare time electioneering for Prof. P. G. Holden. In spite of this however, you can depend upon him when there is work to be done.

name: Trottnow, Ivan C.
comment: "Trot" is the well known "pinch hitter" who scares the south-paw pitchers to death. Is a first class business man and well up in his studies. He and Prof. King are working on the problem of "How to make the boys enjoy the privileges of C. E. Society."

name: Tuttle, Louise E.
comment: A little girl only in stature. Perfectly able to manage her own affairs and has the happy faculty of treating us all alike.

name: Tuttle, Randall M.
comment: Has his own way of doing things. Is a good student and a good fellow. Conscientious in his work and a booster for all college activities.

name: Tydeman, Will
comment: "Tyde" hails from the sunny state to the east of us, but has become so attached to Ames that he spends most of his vacation here. Has classified in at least three different courses during his stay at I.S.C. Is destined to a successful future and the possession of many friends. Chief aid-de-camp to Dr. Tilden at the hospital.

name: Tyler, Merle C.
comment: Exceptional skill and uncommon ability have made "Ty" well known to his classmates. Prefers fiction to the stern realities of life. His mind is in his work but his heart is in California.

name: Ufford, Orville C.
comment: Orville's success depends upon his good looks and his ability to stick. Bashful and very quiet.

name: Vader, Leo C.
comment: 'In spite of all the learned have said, I still my own opinion keep.' Hopes some day to join the Am. Soc. of C.E., but at present he is county surveyor for Pocahontas County. An expert on land drainage.

name: Vale, Bruce R.
comment: A shark he is at some deep scientific studies as well as other subjects. He is a worker and will make good.

name: Van Keuren, Ralph H.
comment: "Van" is sometimes gruff but no one appreciates him until they know him. He made a big hit in the Class Play. He actually made love. How scandalous!

name: Vaughn, Edward
comment: Small but mighty. Cheery smile greets everyone. An all-around college man who can be depended upon to do his best. What is lacking in height is made up in enthusiasm.

name: Vincent, Clarice
comment: For reasons of her own, Clarice has decided not to graduate in the H. Ec. course, but thinks after all the 13's are the best class and wants to be numbered with them. We are proud to own her. She is "specializing" this term in more ways than one.

name: Vincent, Ralph T.
comment: In the classroom, at football, track, or wrestling, "Vince" holds his place unsullied. A good-hearted fellow who speaks when he meets you and is sincere when he greets you. One of the advocates of a Fourth Ward fire department.

name: Vondracek, Lumir J.
comment: "Von" is great at "rough-housing" and pulling off stunts. A brilliant student with a keen wit. Knows his line to perfection and is perfectly willing to show his knowledge.

name: Voss, Lilla
comment: Lilla is the guiding star of a well-known Junior. She has been lately delving into the old editions of "The House Beautiful," evidently with the intention of getting a line on a comfortable cottage with room for two. One of her accomplishments is blushing.

name: Walker, Ben H.
comment: Serious-minded, but a mighty good fellow. Enjoys putting a "good one" over a "Prof" as much as anyone. A brilliant student and everybody's friend.

name: Wallace, Adelbert C.
comment: "Deb" is of a quiet nature and seldom talks without saying something. His curly locks are said to have been the cause of the great hit he made with the short course girls. "Deb" is always near the top in his work.

name: Walls, Mildred
comment: Dispenses food to the hungry at the cafe. Is very likable. Quite partial in her attentions to the stronger sex.

name: Walton, Joseph N.
comment: His smile is his friend maker. Has been reported as a wood sawyer—probably took pattern shop. Walton will win, for he keeps after it all the time.

name: Ward, Harry E.
comment: Cheerful all the time. Can always see the funny side. Is acquiring the fussing habit by going to Margaret Hall to see his sister. A good athlete and a good student.

name: Warner, Jerub H.
comment: A trifle noisy at times but means no offense. Strong on avoirdupois and has a good variety of strong emphatic words. Has ability which he uses at times.

name: Warren, Elgin S.
comment: Always happy and as good-hearted as we ever find 'em. A regular horse if you give him a chance to swim or play ball. Not a shining light in social circles.

name: Warsaw, Wesley W.
comment: "Warse" started out to be an Electrical but decided to get on the fence, so changed to Ag. Eng. He is a good mixer and a regular Walker Whiteside on the stage. His chief delight is a "racket." In fact, he is so handy with a "racket" that he is on the varsity tennis team.

name: Watson, James G.
comment: "Jimmie" is a "foine laddie" from Scotland and a worker. We look for him to do Ames proud. Can talk as well as Bryan himself.

name: Watts, Everett
comment: Quick and energetic. Never seems downhearted and is there all around. Not much of a fusser but loves his Farm Crops studies.

name: Watts, Lyle F.
comment: Never down and out, at least in outward appearance. Doesn't believe in crossing bridges until he comes to them. Will uphold his course at any time.

name: Weirick, Laura
comment: "Pleasure has been the business of my life." A faithful student in H. Ec. Lab. Is there method in her madness? A pretty maid with winsome, merry ways.

name: Weller, Curtis D.
comment: "Lefty's" smiling face has won him many friends all over the campus. Nothing pleases him more than to dish up his "snakey" curves to the opposing batsmen. We expect great things of "Lefty" this year.

name: Welles, Edward S.
comment: Left high school with honors and came to I.S.C. "Skippy" tried the Electrical and then the Industrial Chemistry course, but in his second term struck the final straightaway leading to the goal of medicine. As assistant in the Bacteriology Lab, he is obtaining invaluable practice in applied science. A "shark" at anything he undertakes.

name: Welle, Leon J.
comment: Has much love for the "phyz" department and thinks that "E and M" is the most practical study taught in the institution. Finds no trouble in keeping up with his class. Well liked by all who know him and a student of no small ability.

name: Westbrook, Edwin M.
comment: "Ed" served under Uncle Sam in the Philippines for three years before he decided to become a Civil Engineer. He is a good worker and enjoys the distinction of being able to ask intelligent questions in Hydraulics.

name: Weyrauch, Edward A.
comment: "Eddy" started his college life at Iowa City but he soon saw his mistake and came to Ames. Nothing pleases him better now than to enter into a combat against his old first love. Made his best track record coming out of an apple orchard in the dark. Partial to "school ma'ams."

name: Wheatley, Charles E.
comment: "You can't run no ranicky on Hillsboro." He will make a mighty smart farmer and is always there with the goods. It is hard to get ahead of him in work or word.

name: Wheatley, Ray A.
comment: "Nobody can say I'm bodily lazy." He doesn't agree with the Dutch Department because he is English—in fact, that was his 'ome. He is a "staver" to work, and that means success. Well known at Mankato as a banker and at Drake as an athlete.

name: Whitaker, D. G.
comment: "Dick" is there every time when it comes to meeting a bluff. Always eatin' something so that he can think. Has a good head, and Hillsboro will be proud of it someday.

name: White, H. X.
comment: Quiet and reserved, good-hearted, and willing to help whenever able. A good student and a burner of the midnight oil. Started his educational career at Lake Forest but improved his future chances by coming to I.S.C. to join in the march of the Civil Engineers.

name: Whiting, Fred T.
comment: Full of fun and ambitious. Sharp and believes in keeping up his labs. A close associate of the slide rule, with which he performs phenomenal "exploits." A good mixer and well liked by all who know him.

name: Wilder, Morris B.
comment: A gas engine "expert" and a lover of "joy rides." Of an artistic nature, especially with the crayons and colors. Had a little hard luck in getting started in Mathematics but will be with the bunch in the end. Jolly and well liked.

name: Wills, Miriam H.
comment: "A hall full of just such girls as Miriam would do my heart good."—Mrs. Cunningham. Always in evidence with contagious laughter.

name: Wilson, Charles P.
comment: "Purl" answers to "Chemically Pure" or "Canine Practice," but prefers "Climax Plug." Has great faith in the west and the opportunities it offers. Well liked, and a little more "pep" would make him a fine student.

name: Wilson, David B.
comment: "Dave" wanted to room with someone his size so he picked Juhl. Lives up to the motto of West Liberty by being "Wide Awake" and always keeping things moving. That smile is a constant symptom of his good-naturedness.

name: Wilson, Foster W.
comment: Foster manages to worry along with only 25 hours a week. His generosity is attested by the fact that all of his friends have the habit of saying, "Let George do it."

name: Wilson, Wayne
comment: "Wayne" blew in from Seymour, the metropolis of Wayne County (needless to say whence the county received its name). He gained distinction as a marksman by throwing away the shot in the cement testing machine. In spite of this, however, Wilson is an earnest worker and a true '13.

name: Wise, Leslie O.
comment: "Happy, for all o' that." "Dad" is here getting practical aids to one interested in agriculture. He is a lively chap, and quite a politician. He likes boys better than girls.

name: Wolfe, Anna M.
comment: The above record speaks for itself, and at that, it is incomplete. She has done just a little more than any other girl in the class and has not missed any of the good times. The very keynote of Anna's makeup is "energy."

name: Woody, Ethel
comment: Never worries and everything goes on smoothly. Intends to travel in the old country someday. Makes jest of trouble.

name: Worley, Floyd E.
comment: A loyal Mechanical of no small capacity for knowledge. A fine student and a good mixer. Bright enough to pass up his course without studying, but is here for business and employs his time very profitably.

name: Wormley, Burton H.
comment: Always happy and a great worker. He believes in mixing a few jokes with the college grind. "Variety is the spice of life, you know."

name: Wray, G. Edward
comment: "He is not a gun of great dimensions." "Ed" keeps plugging away, never being known to break the speed limit. His chief claim to fame is that he eats three meals per day. Nevertheless, he has many friends and is loyal to them.

name: Wright, Thomas H.
comment: "Tommy" hasn't decided whether he ever wants to go back to the Phi Phi house or not. Ask him why. "Good Night, Mr. Wright." He is far more than the average student and will do his part in making the dairy industry great.

name: Wygle, Lila
comment: One of those who helps make things go wherever she is—even in the Quantitative Chem. Lab. A "live wire" both in and out of school.

name: Zentmire, Zelma
comment: Never too busy to assist a friend. Helps soothe 'preps' in Chem. Lab. Graduated in the Science course in 1911, but the 1913's are also glad to claim her.
